That is odd to say that the poor in North Korea are happy even through starvation. As a child I was very poor and was hungry all the time. I worried a lot at the age of 7 years old. I found ways to make money to buy a hotdog or a pizza. My childhood was not a happy one. I did find fun at times playing in the streets with other children but majority of the time I stayed up nights waiting for a drunk parent to come home and beat us or what we were going to eat tomorrow. I guess it takes a special type of person to be happy while starving.

America and its western allies should be responsible for the famine in North Korea. North Korea's government intended to trade and maintain peaceful relationships with western countries including America but America refuses to cooperate with its social system. It put on mountainous sanctions on North Korea in the names of freedom and human rights for the North Korean people, hoping the pressure will somehow make Kim surrender or lead to a revolution, just like it is doing in Russia and other enemies, while the fact is these sanctions caused famine in North Korea.  So the solution to this problem is not sanctioning that poor country while telling the world that their leader is insane, this is western hypocrisy and would only make this problem even worse. The only solution today is for the western countries to stop sanctioning North Korea, start sending supplies and offering debts for rebuilding their economy and industry just like what China has been doing for more than five decades, apologize for sanctioning the people, and allow North Korea to participate in international trade. Then this country can reform and open up like China in 1980th.   Now, consider this, would these people ever want to invent nuclear weapon and fire nukes at America if they can live in prosperity? Will the government still enforce restrictions if everyone lives a good life? Remember, "The weapon to kill poverty and restriction is not sanction, its prosperity."

The west's complacency about the welfare of the North Korean people is a disgrace. Given that China is the lifeblood of the North Korean regime, the west should impose on China high tariffs, tariffs that hinge directly on how North Korea treats its people. To the extent North Korea begins treating its people better, the sanctions drop to that extent. If North Korea later regresses to a degree, the sanctions rise to that degree -- in lockstep. As things stand now, China may feel that it benefits in some small-ish, intangible way from North Korea's oppression of its people. The west can readily change China's calculus. Through sanctions we can convert North Korean oppression into large, tangible costs for China. China can avoid these costs by forcing reform in North Korea, which is easily within China's power. We have a responsibility as human beings to the fellow human beings suffering in North Korea. Let's act already!

I put this as a reply to people saying the lady doesn't present with what people assume incorrectly what they think PTSD is:   It's not the opposite of PTSD it's a result of it. It's a total myth when people see an "innocent" looking and jovial person + assume they haven't gone through hardship or horrors hard to imagine.   Some people show truma with a grim countenance. Some people it will show up in other ways like having a chronic illness, autoimmune disease, lowered immune system from depression or stress.   Some signs will be even more invisible than that. But it's a pet peeve of mine when people see a "happy" person and assume they are only like that because they haven't been through as much as the person who has dark circles under the eyes or a sombre atmosphere to them.   Everyone survives differently. Robin Williams laughed with sparkling eyes until he died. People really need to stop assuming and look beyond the 'cover'.  There's also the fact a strong insistence on a sunny focus is the result of being sick of drowning in horrible memories and images. People like that need a break from the constant grim in their minds and nightmares.   Ultimately they can have a deep appreciation for what people take for granted. Simple things like a walk in sunshine or colourful objects could mean the world to someone who has known so much darkness. Think carefully about why someone is drawn to the light. Maybe they want to shine some on the painful darkness you overlooked inside of them.

A lot of people I've talked to about this have a kind of one track approach to the subject. Like: why don't they just revolt! Or sometimes even: they don't know anything about the rest of the world. I'm not sure how I feel about those arguments. Fear is an incredibly powerful weapon, especially fear of not just death, but suffering. There are basically torture camps in north Korea for people who are perceived to have done wrong by the government. Who the hell in their right mind would want to go through that if they could avoid it? As for the latter argument, I don't believe that the lack of information on the rest of the world is due to them willfully ignoring the opportunity of knowledge, but more that this information is just incredibly restricted. In a way, its absolutely true in this case that knowledge is power, and giving the people this power is certainly something that the north Korean government would want to avoid, so they restrict and replace logical knowledge with propaganda in their favor.

Growing up I went too school and had a ton of North Korean and vietnamese friends. As a child I was weirded out when the older Korean people would talk to themselves, pacing heavy, lots of flinching and other mannerisms that made me uncomfortable. As I got older and more educated I learned about trauma and stuff happening in north Korea from other elder North Koreans and it made me sick. Those people who I wrongfully labeled as weird when I was younger probably seen unspeakably horrible tragedies and after a while it weighs on your mental health. These people weren't weird at all, they were traumatized and forced too keep pushing too survive. This is why it's so important as people regardless of what race, gender or religion that we sit and actually talk too each other and have open minds about the different experiences and hurdles we share. You just never know what people go thru or how much you have in common until you just open your heart, mind and ears. My heart is with the people of North Korea ğŸ™ğŸ¿

Iâ€™m Korean, and these days, North Korean defectors are actively engaged in YouTube and broadcasting activities in Korean society.   According to their testimony, in the past, North Korean defectors were severely punished for joint responsibility for their families and relatives.  However, it is said that more than 300,000 North Korean defectors have defected to South Korea, and many of them have actually disappeared because punishing all their relatives will cause the collapse of North Korean society.  I heard that unless political giants such as Hwang Jang-yeop and Tae Young-ho defected from North Korea, the punishment of joint responsibility for the families of North Korean defectors has been weakened to the level of surveillance.   On the contrary, families of North Korean defectors are said to be among the upper class in North Korea because they make money in South Korea and then transfer money to their families remaining in North Korea through brokers.  Among North Koreans, the "Mt. Halla stem" (family of North Korean defectors) is considered the most prestigious rather than the so-called "Mt. Baekdu stem," the Kim family, and the "Mt. Fuji stem," a Korean-Japanese family.  I heard that even North Korean Guards and Labor Party officials who are leading the human rights abuses of North Koreans want to have in-laws with the "Mt. Halla stem" family.   However, since the COVID-19 blockade, the cost of defecting has exceeded $100,000, making it difficult for North Koreans to defect.   There are still many serious problems with human rights in North Korea, but what is comforting is that the experiences of North Korean defectors, especially North Korean defectors, are spreading rapidly in North Korean society and many North Koreans are awakening. This exactly what I was thinking. I complain about how restrictive our culture is. Here, if I try to live my life my own way I will be judged, but I won't be executed.  I complain about how weak our economy is, but I get three (or more ğŸ˜‚) full meals a day, I have a place to stay, I can buy clothes, entertainment... I complain about the lack of opportunity and exposure here. But right now am watching a video from another country through my smartphone. Only last week I was complaing about a series of random power cuts happening in our country. But 90% of the time I have access to electricity.  I want to leave this country but not enough to risk my life or my family  doing it. And I won't be risking anything if I do leave, because I have freedom.  Really puts things in to perspective doesn't it. Reminds us of how blessed we are.

All of my family lived under Stalin, and almost everything that Westerners are taught about life in Soviet Union is bs. Why wouldn't they lie or exaggerate bad things about North Korea?

Â @leviacker1260Â  It's not just the West, but the East as well so don't even blame this on western propaganda. There is clear evidence that from what these people say, the harsh regime in NK exists. Notice how almost all of their stories are similar to one another in regards of starvation and poverty. If NK was so luxurious, then why did these people risk their own lives to try and escape?  As for your point on why so many NKs return to their country, it's most likely due to two factors:  1. They fear that their families back home will suffer because of their action to escape, and therefore, submit to the regime.  2. They are more brainwashed compared to other NKs. Think of it this way. Laughing doesn't always indicate happiness, though. It is often a defense mechanism. Notice that she also laughed (nervously) when she mentioned the flood that wiped out 100,000 people and then she said she didn't know if her family was alive. That's not funny at all, but the brain is amazing... to keep her from dissolving, mentally, the brain allows for the smile and nervous laugh to give adequate serotonin to handle that incredible stress of intense negative emotions.   She also laughs when she discusses the TV watching, but her life was in literal danger. That may get romanticized in movies, but that feeling she describes in an almost tantalizing way, is not a positive emotion.   This doesn't mean every laugh is due to this, but we cannot presume that constant laughter means they are content and fulfilled, or even happy.   On top of that, those who oppress others sometimes laugh as they abuse those around them, which grooms the abused with gaslighting, which throws them off balance. Nervous laughter can be seen by people who are being cruelly mocked by those who are supposed to love and care for them, and I'm guessing the constant smile on "dear leader's" face may come from that same place.   If you convince a people that laughter means happiness, and then groom them to laugh when they experience negative emotions, like we saw, they are less likely to be able to reject the oppression.     Not saying Western civilization is a barrel of monkeys, or anything, but laughter is a complex thing, for sure.

a friend of mine was taken by his dad to watch a public execution as a kid in Vietnam. i don't think it was that bad because it was a shared experience of normative culture, ie it makes sense in the context.  you can talk about it, reference it and there is no potential obligation for you to act, so it's not like you are failing someone or have to keep dark secrets about  witnessing things that don't make sense. kids watch adults to learn how to make sense of such things. especially the internal world of very young children is full of extreme violence, monsters, massacres and graphic bloodshed stories which creates basically a register to later absorb and place such events. to witness schoolyard bullying or their parents divorce may be more traumatizing for kids. note, for example, that boys tend to do particularly bad with amicable divorce, ie the problem is that there's no comprehensible reason. if they marry, they may never be able to trust that their spouse or kids are still there the next day, so you get these very 'insecure attachments' where you don't call back for half an hour and they are basically assuming it's over... but it's extremely taboo to say that for them. a bunch of public slayings are a cakewalk to deal with, by comparison.

The reason the North Korean regime keeps the country as such a brutal Orwellian totalitarian prison-camp rather than allow any freedom or information to pass in or out is because those in charge know that if the North Korean people were ever freed, or if the US or other nations ever invaded and took over, the North Korean leadership would get the death penalty or life imprisonment at best, or simply be dragged through the streets and beaten to death.   If outside powers could ensure (and be good to their word) that the leadership would be taken to another country where they could live in a mansion with anonymity and never suffer any consequences; theyâ€™d take the offer. They both felt that North Koreans were warmer and happier. I knew a girl who grew up in the GDR [East Germany] and was about fifteen when the countries reunified. She said the same thing; the oppression, the deprivation and so on create solidarity among the average citizens. I spent time in the former German Democratic Republic,and I am fluent in German. Compared to the DPRK [North Korea], East Germany was a paradise. But all things are relative; it seemed a terribly impoverished place compared to the Bundesrepublik. These two people interviewed seem very bright and articulate. Some of their experiences were ghastly. But if public executions are what you know, I suppose being shot in front of your family for stealing some metal makes sense. I've spent a great deal of time in places like the former Soviet Union and East Germany,  and while it was repressive in ways, it hadn't been anything like North Korea since the 1930's and Stalin's era.

Yes but she's not wrong in the way that usually people living in the countryside of those poor countries tend to be happier in general because they are not hit by materialism and consumerism as we do. Our problems are nothing compared to theirs. On the pyramid of Maslow, our problems are usually around self-actualization or esteem at the top of the pyramid while theirs are legit physiological and safety needs, the bottom. When you face such tremendous problems on a daily basis, you get happier more easily I'd say since you have more possibility to be happy because you lack a lot of things. On top of that, people from the countryside tend to be less educated hence living a simpler life which also helps with happiness. (There's a correlation between intelligence [ the way they define intelligence is to debate but I guess you understand me huh I'm not saying ppl from the countryside are stupid] and depression) etc....  Based also on my own experience I do agree with that, I've spent some years in Thailand and maaaaan, people from the countryside are so kind, happy to share, less worried and anxious. It's actually quite shocking when you think of it that we, coming from rich ass countries, able to have in most cases more or less whatever we want, tend to be more depressed than the one working hard to barely eat a kg of rice in the week lol .....

Â @WhosPawqÂ  itâ€™s totally not about the Maslow pyramid, itâ€™s about human connection. I had times in my life when I went hungry in a civilized first world country and believe me, I wasnâ€™t happy the slightest bit. Â @benbaselet2026Â  IMHO you're talking about three different things. Western people who listen to fat guys with Ferraris do so voluntarily, with regard to how they can change their own personal stories. People in NK don't think about their personal stories, they listen to Kim Jong-Un because they believe he's the only source of truth and get punished if they don't listen to him. They would listen to him even if he wasn't rich and fat, because that's the way the country works. And the reasons why people listened to priests changed throughout history. So I wouldn't give churches as an example of this... I'm not Catholic but in grudging fairness to them, that was a slightly different thing.   First, churches were the meeting places, the administrative centres for weddings and funerals, they could provide asylum, some of them housed schools and served as fortresses with underground escape routes when necessary. When my town was sieged in 1434, the people took refuge in the church. So they weren't useless.   Second, for a big chunk of Middle Ages, people couldn't understand a word the priest was saying because the priests spoke in Latin. So the priests couldn't really have fed them any lies in churches. Can you imagine rich guys with Ferraris or Kim Jong-Un only speaking a language nobody understands?    Third, going to church on Sunday was mostly a matter of course. People went to churches for example because they were forced to, because they were used to it, because they wanted to sing and to have a chat afterwards, or because they wanted a bit of peace and quiet, or because they were actual believers. I didn't get the impression most people went to churches to admire someone who was powerful and richer than them. (The priest was a local person and his housekeeper had female friends in the village, you know?... everyone knew the priest's property didn't prevent him from having arthritis or stomach problems. Imagine Kim Jong-Un's housekeeper telling the whole nation "the boss has farted again, oh sh*t, I'm fed up with opening the windows all the time."?) So we aren't talking a personality cult here.   Fourth, it wasn't like that for millennia, more like 600 years (late Middle Ages - about the 19th century). Before that, the church fulfilled its function, like the monasteries treating sick people for free, giving people herbs, advice, education and whatnot. So one of the reasons the people flocked there was because they could get actual help. The sad fact was that NK was a normal country until 1992 (a huge famine took place). What happened that when USSR dissolved, no one was there to keep trading with them. It is like growing up and not taking a toy you really liked from the closet anymore, but instead of a teddy bear it was a wohole country. The famine sprung up, newly ruling Kim Jong-Il handled it really badly and prolonged the crisis. Then NK was without any money, its jewel-the Ryugyong Hotel was put on a hiatus (it is now just a fancy display of news) and never finished. They were left totally drained and couldn't function anymore. But times were getting better, and they were going to be just a strange country. However then middle east turned into a warzone and fearing occupation, the Juche ideology dictated: put everything you have in army. The better times they were looking forward never came.

Walking through Chinatown, a tourist is fascinated with all the Chinese restaurants, shops, signs and banners.  He turns a corner and sees a building with the sign, "Hans Olaffsenâ€™s Laundry." "Hans Olaffsen?", he muses. "How the heck does that fit in here?" So he walks into the shop and sees an old Chinese gentleman behind the counter. The tourist asks, "How did this place get a name like 'Hans Olaffsenâ€™s Laundry?'" The old man answers, "Is name of owner." The tourist asks, "Well, who and where is the owner?" "Me, is right here," replies the old man. "You? How did you ever get a name like Hans Olaffsen?" "Is simple," says the old man. "Many, many year ago when come to this country, was stand in line at Documentation Center. Man in front was big blonde Swede. Lady look at him and go, 'What your name?' He say, 'Hans Olaffsen.' Then she look at me and go, 'What your name?'  I say, 'Sem Ting.'"

Â S SÂ  Holodomor was genocide. The russians invaded. The russians took the food and sent it home. The russians searched house to house regularly and took the food and sent it home. There was no famine in ukrane, the famine was in russia. The reasons for the famine are a subject of scholarly and political debate. Some scholars suggest that the man-made famine was a consequence of the economic problems associated with changes implemented during the period of Soviet industrialisation.[52][29][53] There are also those[who?] who blame a systematic set of policies perpetrated by the Soviet government under Stalin designed to exterminate the Ukrainians.[citation needed]  The collectivisation policy was enforced, entailing extreme crisis and contributing to the famine. In 1929â€“30, peasants were induced to transfer land and livestock to state-owned farms, on which they would work as day-labourers for payment in kind.[54] Collectivization in the Soviet Union, including the Ukrainian SSR, was not popular among the peasantry and forced collectivisation led to numerous peasant revolts. The first five-year plan changed the output expected from Ukrainian farms, from the familiar crop of grain to unfamiliar crops like sugar beets and cotton. In addition, the situation was exacerbated by poor administration of the plan and the lack of relevant general management. Significant amounts of grain remained unharvested, and â€“ even when harvested â€“ a significant percentage was lost during processing, transportation, or storage.[citation needed]  In the summer of 1930, the government instituted a program of food requisitioning, ostensibly to increase grain exports. Subsequently, in 1932, food theft was made punishable by death or 10 years imprisonment.[54]  It has been proposed that the Soviet leadership used the man-made famine to attack Ukrainian nationalism, and thus it could fall under the legal definition of genocide.[55][56][52][57][25][58] For example, special and particularly lethal policies were adopted in and largely limited to Soviet Ukraine at the end of 1932 and 1933. According to Snyder: "[E]ach of them may seem like an anodyne administrative measure, and each of them was certainly presented as such at the time, and yet each had to kill."[59][60] Under the collectivism policy, for example, farmers were not only deprived of their properties but a large swath of these were also exiled in Siberia with no means of survival.[61] Those who were left behind and attempted to escape the zones of famine were ordered shot. There were foreign individuals who witnessed this atrocity or its effects. For example, there was the account of Arthur Koestler, a Hungarian-British journalist, which described the peak years of Holodomor in these words:  At every [train] station there was a crowd of peasants in rags, offering ikons and linen in exchange against a loaf of bread. The women were lifting up their infants to the compartment windows â€“ infants pitiful and terrifying with limbs like sticks, puffed bellies, big cadaverous heads lolling on thin necks.[62] You should read the letters and books written by people from Ukraine at that time.

North Korea gets away with this because of China. I'm sorry if the "truth" makes you uncomfortable, but this is pretty much fact.   Not because China necessarily approves of what NK does to its' own people (hence why they specifically do not turn back Koreans who flee from NK anymore, like they used to decades ago), but because China, in their paranoia, still thinks that "The West" will invade their country at any possible moment, and so they tolerate North Korea as a handy "Buffer State." Why North Korea, and not Mongolia, or Vietnam? Because the Chinese view South Korea as the most likely launch-point of any potential land-based invasion of China. And North Korea stands firmly between that, and China's border.   One needs only look at how this works by going back to the Korean War, in the 1950's. American troops, within just a few weeks, had North Korea almost entirely conquered, right up to within ten miles of the Chinese Border of Manchuria, and then, with no warning whatsoever, 150,000 Chinese soldiers poured across the river and reinforced the broken North Korean Army with sheer numbers, and literal mountains of weaponry. America was so stunned by this move, that they were pushed back to where the demarcation line currently stands before they got their act together, and recovered from the surprise. The remaining two years of that war were nothing but a perfectly frustrating "stalemate." The idea of using Nukes to silence China's interference was floated several times (but thankfully that brilliant idea was tossed aside as "insane" and never implemented... none of us would be alive today if that crap actually went down...).   If any country in the world (doesn't even have to be the USA, if it were ANYBODY not named China) ever tried to "liberate" North Korea's populace from the abuse they are administered on a daily basis, China would not hesitate to "intervene" with maximum ferocity, once again. Because North Korea "belongs" to China (they just refuse to proclaim that out loud)! Any western country, USA, or otherwise, that crosses that demilitarized zone with even so much as a single soldier, will potentially get the entire Chinese Army on their ass in two days flat. In the People's Republic's eyes, an invasion of North Korea is to be treated the same as an invasion of China itself.   This would be like some army landing in Quebec, trying merely to conquer the Canadians. But then the United States Army shows up, full force, and demands: "Hey there, Clown, what're ya'll doing in our back yard??"

Â @KetutarÂ  Actually @Christian Valencia is mostly right. Detachment, dissociation, derealization - these are normal consequences of serious trauma. That's why soldiers develop a messed up, inhuman sense of humour in war (e.g. playing with body parts). They get desensitized. And then years after all those emotions have been repressed, when friends/loved ones are asking them to "be normal", they have PTSD, because their emotions have been warped, and instead comes out in volatile bursts. That's repression, and it's *not in their control at all*.  Emotional detachment is designed to protect you psychologically, when there's too much pain to handle. Worst still, if you get pregnant in that level of continuous stress, your stress hormones turn on a genetic switch in your baby, 'telling it' to be highly anxious all the time, to get ready to survive in a dangerous, stressful world.   These are all mechanisms that helped our ancestors survive in the wild, but they mess us up in warzones.
for many, being cold or laughing while describing horrible memories is a coping mechanism. after many years, its only natural to compartmentalize their emotions when remembering these things.

So did they just up and decided to escape one day without telling anyone in their family? 2. If so, wouldn't their neighbors ask where they were if they hadn't seen them in several days/weeks/months? 3. If so, what would their families answer? And why wouldn't they be executed immediately because they could not account for a person whom they could normally account for? 4. If the families did know they were going to flee - did they beg them not to do it for fear that they would executed if it was found out? What story did they come up with to explain the sudden disappearance of a family member? Did they have to fake a death? And if so, wouldn't they need some kind of proof someone died? 5. The one girl said she walked into China - well, what happened when she got to China? Did she speak Chinese? Was she homeless for a while? How did she get food, clothes, money for her phone and the phone she sent back to her family? And the NK government was not censoring people's mail? Seems like receiving a non-approved/non-tapped phone in the post could be cause for execution if simply stealing a piece of rope could be. 6. What are all these people doing now for a living? Are any of them activists or are they living in fear and/or under assumed names?   7. What papers do that have that are acceptable proof of citizenship of anywhere? Did they escape with birth certificate, social security card, passport, state ID (or whatever the NK equivalents would be)? How much money did they have to pay in bribery to the soldiers? And how much money, if any, did they escape with?     I'm so confused as to how/why they decided to escape given all the odds against them. They are extremely brave, for sure. And more background info would be helpful to know. I know I may not get answers to these questions, so thanks for providing a space for the conversation.

I don't understand the premise nor motivation here.  No halfway intelligent person criticizes or trashes the PEOPLE who live in (or rather, are daily victimized by the government of) North Korea. Most of us know the crimes of the government do not reflect the character of the citizen subjected to it.   I really don't like this trend of creating a false "problem" just to justify an "answer." I hate the North Korean government; I don't hate the people. I criticize and condemn the North Korean government; I don't criticize and condemn the people.   Anyone who genuinely can't make the distinction is in a very small minority and can't be considered a real issue that needs a response.  Also why are you centering solely on "Young" defectors? Why not all ages? This is just more Gen Z/Young Millennial baiting. Just kinda phoning it in. Frankly, and I'm sorry if this sounds mean, but I'd rather hear the stories of someone who lived 30 or 40 years in the DPRK over someone who lived 12 or 20 years in the DPRK.  This is just more generation baiting for views, clicks and comments.   Also asking someone why the chose to defect, when they defected at 12? They didn't choose to defect at all, their parents did. I'd like to hear why the parents did. And the responses being given are too samey, too canned. They don't ring of any personal internalization. Again, this is just generational clickbait masquerading as something better than that.   And finally, what really makes me sick, is that there are some things being said in that video that the astute mind will catch on are not true; they are brainstormed "Hey let's think about a terrible thing that could believably happen, and then put it in the video like it really happened." YOU DON'T NEED TO DO THAT AND THE FACT THAT YOU DID THAT MAKES A MOCKERY OF YOUR INTEGRITY AND UNDERMINES ANY GOOD YOU ARE TRYING TO ACCOMPLISH!

It the paradox of the human condition. Happiness is a function of expectations. Low expectations in life = happy. However it also causes complacency & allows people to be mistreated/exploited, with them doing little to improve their condition. Â @LordPrometheousÂ  First of all, censorship in the media exists for the sole reason of things possibly being traumatic to some viewers, so your point here is wrong. Memory of an event may not be outright "proof of traumatization", but a detailed recount of an experience is definitely something that happens when people become traumatized. In this case? Yes it is necessarily traumatic. He sat next to the family, he knew the man's story, he knew it was wrong, and he had to witness an unjust killing by mandate of law. It's not the same when you pass a horrible car crash because you usually don't know what happened or what their story is. Maybe the person who crashed was a murderer. You don't know, so you can't feel bad. But man, when I hear about kids dying, it destroys me inside, every single time. I have to stop listening to the news sometimes. Heck, I had to stop this very video because that story of violence affected me that much. I'm 38, so I don't think that the trauma of thinking about unjust suffering is becoming less traumatizing for me ever. If anything, it's gotten worse over the years as I've gained more empathy for others as I've gained life experience.

Â @LordPrometheousÂ  do you see massacred bodies of people who die in accidents every time there is an accident? Do you see blown off heads when you read news about a shootout? In North Korea there is a very brutal way of execution that you are forced to watch. At some point you get desensitized to the view, like a paramedic called to an accodent site, but it doesn't mean the first times are not traumatic.

Stereotypes: - It is one of the most militarized societies in the world. True. -Much of the NK military is infected with HIV. True. -NK policies have led to a wave of famine and starvation the likes of which have not been seen since Stalin. True. -The NK's believe that the world will take them more 'seriously' if they have nuclear weapons. True. Side note, does anyone take India or Pakistan 'more seriously' now that they have nukes? Quick answer: No. They are more dangerous, but only to each other. -NK society is dystopian as Hell. For example, in Pyongyang [a city where almost no one can get permission to own, much less afford to buy, a private car] there are traffic direction police on duty 24 hours a day. True. -The NK justice system is barbaric. True. -The NK secret service has been kidnapping Japanese citizens for years. True. Um, bruh, it ain't a stereotype if it's true. And I'm not talking about a 'grain of truth' here. Everything point I have made here can be confirmed by multiple news agencies and open-source intelligence. North Korea [because it is in no way a 'republic' nor does it belong to any 'people' other than the Jong-il family] is so buggered up that it makes Orwell's '1984' look like a hopeful dissertation of dewy-eyed optimism.

Â @kepsenmzÂ   France is not designated a socialist country if that is what you mean. It is true that they have socialist policies like welfare programs, public education, a progressive income tax etc etc... However, France has a balanced economy that to some extent allows the market forces to flourish, just like most countries.  When it comes to North Korea, the situation is completely different. There, the inhabitants relies on the government to provide for them and there are no competitors that can challenge the state monopoly of the economy. This is extremely dangerous, not only because it allows for power to be centred around one single institution (instead of divided which is one of base pillars of the French constitution), but also because it denies the human need to compete - an instinct that is hundreds of millions of years old. In other words: Capitalism is not only an ideology, it is the economic equivalent to natural evolution and therefore also a reflection of ourselves. Capitalism and its market forces are not bad and evil elements, they just needs some regulations and steering in order to benefit us and our civilization.

This is all so sad to hear, but it also spreads misinformation about capitalism, socialism and communism. This is a dictatorial regime that calls itself socialist, but that doesn't mean it's actually functioning that way. The Amish and other communal societies function quite well without starving their people to death. Also, markets are not the same thing as capitalism. Bartering systems function all over the world and are distinct from capitalism, which is a system that focuses on imbuing something with little material value (i.e. gold or paper) with fictitious value so that it can be traded for items that are of actual use/value (i.e. food, tools, etc). It saves the step of needing to decide how much rice you're willing to part with for this bunch of apples, but it also eventually leads to advanced capitalism where money is treated as having value in itself not just the value it brings in being able to purchase things you actually use.

My dad used to live near the North Korean border, in the outer parts of Fushun near Shenyang in northern China. Can confirm that when I lived with him there for a while there's a LOT of plastic bottles everywhere. My dad would collect them because I think if you return a certain amount you get a few cents worth back. We'd drink bottled water only and we'd just throw the empty bottles into a corner so once we had enough we could recycle them. Even when we went out into the country where the sky is actually blue, there's rubbish and plastic bottles thrown in the rivers still. It also gets very very cold up there. Winter in Fushun was -30 degrees Celsius, the rivers do freeze over completely.

It's great and equally important to let their voices be heard, but I would've censored their faces and left out the specific escape route. Why? In North Korea if a member of a family defects they will kill, torture, or hold for ransom the family still in North Korea. The demons who run North Korea have access to the internet, etc, and if they trace a defectors face or name even those affiliated with them could suffer, even if they have done no wrong of their own. That's the face censoring. Second, I would've bleeped out the escape route. While it's heartbreaking hearing about the bottles and conditions, specifying the route only serves to have the dictator more thoroughly guard, patrol, or restrict areas specified, making it harder, riskier, if not more impossible for others to defect on that route. It only serves to make what is already dangerous even more so. Sadly we don't live in an ideal world. So while their escape is to be appreciated, you can't be naive about the horrendous people and what they will do following that. I pray for you all.

There is a natural cycle between expressing public grievances and governance improvement, either pushing for reform or or slowing down the abuse of state power. However, when a strong foreign threat is present, it disrupts this healthy cycle. Be it the ongoing economic siege on NK, the war game with Japan and South Korean since 1953, or non-stop threatening of militaristic punishment, you make extremely easy for Kim Jong Un to dismiss public grievance as â€œoverreaction of individuals misled by foreign propaganda", or to justify crackdown on civil disobedience as "preserving national sovereignty against foreign instigators", and to shift the blame on economic disaster (i.e., the famine) caused by communism to imperialism from abroad, such as hundreds of US military bases, dishonest mainstream media, and economic siege (i.e., sanctions on NK). Other examples are governments of Iran, Venezuela, and China, who are so corrupt, so oppressive, yet they survive, because, like James Madison once said, "If Tyranny and Oppression come to this land (Iran, Venezuela, China, and NK), it will be in the guise of fighting a foreign enemy (the US, Israel, and the west in general)." For anyone who sympathize with the plight of people in NK (and Iran, Venezuela, China, etc.), please call your senators, ask them to vote against any intervention no matter how humane it sounds, be it special force deployment, funding the rebels by the CIA and the State Department with your tax dollars, economic sanctions that starves the people more while empowering Kim Jong Un more; ask them to vote to stop the annual war games which not only cost your tax dollars, but also glorifies Kim Jong Un's dictatorship as heroic as protecting national sovereignty against enormous aggression from the most powerful nations on earth.

I would agree -- people in any country often claim that life in the past was better than today, or to claim that the past was a "simpler" time. Folks will say this and then point out changes in technology or to current news events to try to back up this impression. Under genuine scrutiny, these claims usually don't hold up well. When I hear claims like this I just suggest the person dig out some archived newspaper from 50 years ago and read a few pages.   In this case however, both of these folks essentially say the same thing --- people in South Korea are colder, more driven and more alienated from one another. Tyler while I agree with everything that you said, I think we DO have to take her on her word.  It is hard for us as individuals who did NOT grow up in this level of poverty to TRULY comprehend the truth in her words, but I know that even for myself who grew up in a family of 7 with absolutely NOTHING extra, I very much resonate with what she said.  it was our lack of extra that imprinted in me the importance of the little things in life like family, unity, togetherness, self control and optimism.  My ENTIRE life people have asked me where my joy, my personality, my grateful disposition comes from and I have always told people that when you are raised with little, you find the beauty in the nothingness. . . In the simply being here.  In the everything that you DO have.  In my family you did not eat until you were full because there was not enough food to get you full.  There was enough for us.  ALL of us.... and everyone got some.  I didn't eat breakfast and dinner's were small but we had each other and that was LITERALLY the only thing that mattered.  I KNEW how hard it was on my mom because I would see her cry sometimes BUT still, we were happy.  Keep in mind this upbringing was in the U.S. where we could easily compare our lives to the lives of friends at school who DID have wealth.  Now extrapolate this to a community in North Korea that has never even SEEN prosperity.  I would imagine that many of them do not even KNOW what the outside world looks like.  All they know is survival through each other so as long as you have each other you are happy.  It is not so common to yearn for things you do not know even exist when your reality is grounded in survival through each other.  Later in life I had the privilege to go to a very expensive private university and some of my absolutely wealthiest friends were the most unhappy individuals.  They could do whatever they wanted, and as a result were constantly looking for validation and purpose in all the things they COULD do, which led to massively empty, unhappy and unfulfilled lives.  This of course was not all of them, but, because of the life I have been so fortunate to live in all it's varying scopes, it resonates as clear as day to me that people with little are often happier than those who have much.  This is why we ALL know the age old adage: "Money cannot buy you happiness".

I am from South Korea and I've been into North Korean people(Refugees), so I've watched so many TV shows and documentaries about them broadcasted in Korea. Sometimes, some refugees on TV weekly show programs disappeared without any notice. This is true story that one female popular refugee on several Korean TV shows was suddenly vanished. Even Korean police officers who had a duty to care about her, were not aware of her disappearance. So, they tried to catch her and many South Korean people were curious about it. Then a few days later, she was suddenly shown on a North Korea's propaganda broadcast out of nowhere.... that was pretty much shocking cuz she appeared on South Korean TV not that long ago before her disappearance. The police finally announced that North Korean police agency was often threatening her about her family members living in North Korea as hostages. The North Korean government let her family call her and then tell like this "we are very suffering from poverty under their extreme surveillance because of your escape alone but they said if you come back to here again, they will definitely forgive everything and offer the best   life quality for us. So, that's why she went back. She had no choice for her family at that time. When she appeared on NK's TV, it seemed that she had a haircut by force, dying her hair black and had a swollen face (probably assaulted). Except her case, I saw many refugees stopped being shown on TV in the same reason. I don't hope Sunny has the same problem.. just wish her happiness somewhere.

Itâ€™s almost nothing compared, but when hurricane Katrina hit, my family lost everything. My mother lost her job and got injured, she was unable to work, we had to live in womenâ€™s shelters, me, my mom and my 3 siblings. It was hard seeing so many other people that lost who they were because of the tragedy, but those other families we met became our rocks and we supported each other, fed each other, and worked together to get by for a few years. All of these families were in some way injured, making it hard for the parents to work. There was never judgement and we were all equals just making sure everyone had enough clothes, food and support. It was beautiful. I wouldnâ€™t want it again, but I made some of my best friends by living that way.

My mom's family is just north of Seoul but took forever back then as the roads were not developed.  I went in 86 at 7 years old.  It was still almost like a country side. Houses (old pagoda style) had outhouses. But her whole family was close, most living in the small house.  Neighborhood kids playing outside everywhere, catching grasshoppers, there was a river, people washing clothes, neighbors dropping by, big family feasts, hanging out late, so many flies where the lights were,  I went back in 2011...  Boy, did it change.  Everybody was separate, distant, too busy, working so hard to pay for their rent.  No sense of community, major class differences.  That creek and field was gone, and replaced by a pristine park.  Families now only had 1 kid, nobody really playing or interacting with each other.  Talk about a difference.  So yes, being poor, bunched up, not having to live the individual asset accumulation life does lead to isolation and a coldness.  Alot of North Koreans talk about missing the warmness of their neighbors.

ì™•ë”° ; memedy   Learn Hangul first and well. I recommend watching Go! Billy and his â€œLearn Hangul in 90 minutes.â€ Video on YouTube. Get a notebook and write down everything and listen to what he says. Repeat. (Of course youâ€™re not going to learn in 90 minutes but his video is good and you can pause and refer back to it.).   (Billy also has three (slightly expensive unless you get the ebooks) textbooks with full Korean lessons.    Then find Korean grammar videos and use the website KoreanClass101 (the site takes a bit of time to get use to but it is quite helpful.) also watch their YouTube videos.  I also recommend you change as much in your life as you possibly can to Korean. (Listen to kpop, watch Korean movies/cartoons/dramas, use the Korean keyboard (standard) on your phone.)  Flash cards are useful.   Patience, perseverance and practice is key. Because it will get very confusing and difficult at times. Keep in mind it will take months or years to learn. Practice speaking, sounding out, reading and writing Korean everyday.   You could try apps if you want too. You could also try to find someone who speaks Korean and speak with them.   Speaking is also key. Trial and error. Mistakes and embarrassment will more than likely occur.   Find a reliable method but a method that works for you.   Learn a little bit about Koreaâ€™s history and history of their language/s. Also learn about their cultures and ways.  Donâ€™t rely on and donâ€™t use romanisation to write. Yes, it does seem easier but you wonâ€™t be understood. Use romanisation only as a guideline to help you pronounce words.  Try to learn the formal and informal language.   Learn like a little kid learning their first language. (Even though itâ€™s a bit annoying and no one needs to know) kids shows, worksheets, kids songs etc.    Visit Korea (South, unless youâ€™re brave). (Okay so this probably isnâ€™t doable for most people but yeah.)
I recommend starting off with talktomeinkorean and using memrise or anki for vocab. It's important to practice, so I also recommend finding Koreans to talk to, perhaps with hellotalk.

God, I hate it when people blame Western or prosperous countries for other countries' starvation. Yes, global hunger is an extremely big issue, but there is a much bigger and more significant reason on why it happens, and it's not because of wasted food. Global hunger is because of improper distribution, and this occurs because the world generally runs on capitalism. 95% of food is not owned by the government, but by private corporations and companies. The government cannot simply take surplus foods off of supermarket shelves and give them to North Korea or any other starving country. Sure, the government definitely has the ability to do that, but that would create conflict, since the people of any country don't want their tax money being spent to feed another country.  It's up to private corporations and companies, or aid groups, or even simple individuals to send food to other countries. But in North Korea's case, they're not going to accept any donations from Americans. In fact, the United States of America, the United Nations, and other countries have TRIED to donate food and rice to North Korea. But guess what Kim Jung Un did with them? He literally gave all of the food, which was meant for the civilians, to the North Korean army. He also sold some of it and spent it on military equipment.   You seriously cannot blame Americans because of wasted food. If Americans do not eat what is on the shelves, then companies and private corporations will literally just move to another country. They'll go to China, or Europe, and then people will be blaming these "Damn Europeans wasting food!" Right now, there is AN INSANE amount of food-- enough to end world hunger. But guess what? It's the bad distribution of food that is causing it

The problem isn't waste, is getting there without spoiling, and into the right hands.  In a country like NK, corruption is so bad that without change, all the help by sending food won't change a thing.  You think the US has an elite problem, its magnified in countries like NK, who would horde the incoming food and money for themselves, or those they see fit to give it to.

+Nikki Narrates I think of myself as an average American, and I'm thankful for every day I have in this country. It seems like the human brain needs to have something to strive towards and be envious of though, maybe thats how we move forward in everything. It is easy to forget the hardships of other places around the world in our own bubbles of our lives and get mad at the internet disconnecting or having to go to school. I always at the end of the day have a big smile on my face at just how amazing my life is and it makes me so angry that the North Korean people have to go through this. We get a new TV for our birthday and they get a serving of white rice. It's sickening.

+Taunic and that is why people watch videos like these - it makes their lives seem better by comparison. I donâ€™t like it because it often takes advantage of the weak (where our clothing comes from, children in factories in places like cambodia.) and cripples the masses (one percent have control, hard for unions to gain power, etc.) in terms of power. And itâ€™s incredibly wasteful: look at the food market. We throw out and bleach good food so that it canâ€™t be eaten because it doesnâ€™t look nice. I understand we are where we are because of it, but it doesnâ€™t mean that I like it or that I think things should stay the same.

It seems to me that you're against capitalism as implemented in the US. I many other countries where capitalism is implemented, people are paid a living wage. I live in a capitalist country, there is little social support but very low taxes.   In fact, if you make minimum wage you don't pay income tax at all. Your food bill is barely 10% of your salary, room rent is maybe 20%, transport maybe 15%, so you get to save more than half your salary and this is on minimum wage.   This leaves a lot of people with a lot of money in the bank. Many will reinvest the money, thus funding others who start new businesses to cater for the demand of the people who have money (which is pretty much everyone.)   This makes them a lot of money, which most will reinvest.. you get the idea. This is what happens in many capitalist countries.   This in a nutshell is capitalism - people spend, make others rich, they spend, and make others rich, and so on. It's not capitalism's fault that people choose to hoard money or be really short term.   If one percent of the population have control of everything, it's no longer a capitalist economy :) A capitalist economy is as I have described above. Everyone needs something and/or wants something. Because of that he will need money. He can only get money by providing something people want or need. One person or group cannot control everything because they can't possibly provide everything everyone wants, and have nothing they need or want in return :)  Because of this, it's kind of silly to say one percent can control the economy - they can't make everything everyone wants, and they have needs and wants which will require them to depend on others.  As for the children in Cambodia. If you were in a centrally planned economy, you'd only have one set of clothing - the children in Cambodia would be starving because of no demand. There would be no real economy to speak of, their lives would be controlled by a government.   The children in Cambodia only survive BECAUSE of capitalism - people always want new t-shirts, who doesn't have a whole lot of t-shirts? :) there's no reason for anyone to have a closet full of t-shirts, but they do because capitalism right? that's the best part of capitalism - they want more t-shirts because they are greedy, but at the same time they unconsciously help others survive by gratifying their needs, wants and desires :)  This throwing out, bleaching and cleaning thing only really happens in the US, I have no idea why that is. Over here the eggs aren't cleaned, sometimes you can even see chicken poop on them. Stores do with almost expired stuff what any capitalist would do, sell them at reduced prices.   It's good that you understand that you are where you are because of what the people demand, but that again is not because of capitalism, it's because that's what people want and will pay for. It's partly because the US is almost a monoculture - about 76% (more than three quarters) identify as "white" and by and large pretty much share the same culture.   So pretty much everyone lives the same way, likes the same things, thinks the same way, eats the same things, wears the same clothing, and pretty much have the same wants and desires. In a monoculture, if everyone wants all the same things, and you don't, it might be a bit of a struggle. That is not the result of capitalism but more the result of a monoculture.   Unions are not a capitalist thing - in fact unions are anti-capitalist because they constantly attempt to manipulate salaries. In a real capitalist economy, if you paid low wages people would just leave for companies that pay more. The idea that someone would choose to work for a company, and then try to force them to pay more is strange,   It makes one wonder why they don't start their own businesses or go work for someone else.  PS. Have you read George Eliot's "MIddlemarch" ? there's someone in there with your first name, that sounds exactly like you :)

It's not really happiness, it's called being content. When you're in such bad state, you're always aware of how much worse it could be, the things others are going through. For example if you're a man working for 5$ a month, you think about those who don't have fixed jobs or incomes and are starving. And those are thinking of the ones in Labor Camps, working day and night without gaining anything in return. And if you're one of those, you think that it could be better than a public execution or being tortured to death. You always know that there is something that's worse, that there's someone praying to be in your place... you kind of count every little blessing. Also, the people tend to be closer and more protective, specially if they're limited to such or such area, cause everyone becomes your family and you worry about them as if they're your responsibility, to a certain point of course. I don't think any of that stands for happiness, it's just... another word for unity.

Not too long ago, i found out about my grandfathers past. Although he passed away 10 years ago, he never told me (i was 6 at the time he died)  about his two older brothers. He and his 2 younger brothers moved to South Korea when tensions escalated between the two Korea's before the Korean War.  His two older brothers decided to stay behind and when the war came, all connection was severed. Similarly, my grandmother left behind everything to escape to China. She left behind money, family, friends, and a home at the age of 17. She eventually moved to South Korea, married my grandfather, then moved here in the late 70's.  The people who praise North Korea don't understand what the North Korean people go through everyday and it hurts to know that i have family in North Korea. What scares me even more is that they may be in a concentration/work/death camp.  Kim Jong Un needs to be tortured by his own people until he dies. This man needs to suffer for causing over 3 generations of dictatorship and needs to die slowly. I am proud of my North Korean ancestry and will display it proudly, but the leadership of that country needs to die now. Revolution must occur and true democracy must be restored. Democracy is non-negotiable, it is given or withheld. I hope by the end of this year, we can eradicate communism from that country once and for all

+NorthKorean Sunny First of all thank you for sharing your story. I was wondering what your opinion is on intervention if any. Would you want to see the West with SK march in and topple the government? What do you think would be the best way to change NK? Not an easy question, sorry.  Would the people even be ready for any kind of intervention or are they too indoctrinated?  I have thought about what could be done at times but most things seem to be prone to making things worse. E.g. we could try to pressure NK with more sanctions but with how the government apparently seems to operate this will just mostly affect the people. We could try and march in and assume the military bravado really is just bravado and that we can mop it up easily with superior technology but we might be seen as invaders if we do.  NK seems to me to be a difficult problem to solve and I'm not sure involvement by the west is even desired by people in the region?  Cheers from Europe!

Here's the real story. Every defector that jumps the fence from north Korea is regarded by the south Korean government as a potential spy.  Every defector is interrogated for weeks by south Korean intelligence agents to make sure they're not a spy. Every defector will say whatever south Korean intelligence agents want them to say to prove they're not a spy.  It's illegal to say anything positive about north Korea in south Korea. Therefore, whatever the north Korean defector says will be all bad.  If a north Korean defector says anything good about their former homeland, they're a spy and they're put into prison. After many weeks of interrogation, and after trashing their former homeland, the north Korean defector is finally given what they came for in the first place: a smartphone and a coupon for a Big Mac with Fries and a chocolate shake. There are no McDonald's restaurants in north Korea.

Hypatia4242  The difference is that, in the case of an air drop to North Korea, the drop would occur  in the air space over a hostile nation. With the Berlin air drop, the U.S. was dropping humanitarian relief to an ally, namely, the West German citizens living in (as well as Western Allies' occupying forces stationed in) the besieged West Berlin sector. When the U.S. air drop occurred, it was no surprise to the Soviet occupying forces nor to the East German government. On the other hand, the paranoid, belligerent North Korean dictatorship (eager to act on its own outrageous propaganda, no less) might view an air drop as an act of war and would not hesitate to shoot down the planes. It should be remembered that North Korea is still officially in a state of war with the U.S. and South Korea. Despite tensions between the U.S. and the Eastern Bloc nations under the Soviet Union, there was no state of war that existed between the former allies. It would have been incredibly bad public relations for the Soviet-supplied East German military to shoot down the aircraft of an "ally."

@Jeremy Kather That's an important point. One might feel justified dismissing the validity of someone's suffering in the US to the point of suicidal escape. Where they have no perspective. But my experiential evidence doesn't prove as much. I suppose because one's environment defines "much" if not all of one's perspective.  Where most of my entire Korean family were tortured and slaughtered during the JeJU massacre... And though many of my family survivors would not exist if my Grandmother did not predict the turmoil : fleeing and hiding as many as she could... Escaping and becoming US citizens was of course a blessed privilege! But as continued success and prosperity was realized that hardly dismisses hardships and tragedy.  Not just obvious events like death in the family or health tragedies. But even events one might assume are trivial in comparison... Such as losing a job promotion/college picks etc... that would had enabled one's dreams/passion.  A failed relationship/Divorce/Parents divorce. Infertility.  No one escapes horrific oppression who struggling for their life and their "dreams"...  only to "settle" if they finally make it to the land of opportunity.  Everyone's tragedies r exactly that. A tragedy.  Also... Health concerns add an extra layer of consideration.  Depression is now designated as Major Depressive mood disorder because to many people confuse as much with a simple "choice". Which is hell for someone who has a coping disease living in a society  that expects them to simply cope.  With that said.... Yes I still feel extremely lucky that my tragedies are owned by a blessed life.

North Korea is probably the worst of the nations that are still Communist, but horrors like these escapees describe take place, to varying degrees in all Communist nations.  There has been starvation due to lack of food caused by poor management, or due to government attempts to subjugate certain regions.  There is government control over what the people may read, whether or not there is any religious practice permitted, where people may work and how much they must produce, what the children learn in schools, etc.  Neighbor spies upon neighbor, children spy on their parents, reporting infractions to the government.  There is poor medical care, or none at all.  People line up for days for the chance to buy a pair of ill-fitting shoes.    In spite of the terrible history of Communism, foolish people in the free and prosperous nations of the West still read Communist and Socialist writings and embrace the ideas, and try to convert their own nations to Communism.  History and reality mean nothing to such fools, so any of us who see the truths of Communist tyranny must be alert, and do all we can to teach and dissuade those who believe the lies, even fighting them if they use violence.  The thought of losing individual and societal liberty to such evil is unbearable.  Listen to what the people who have escaped such evil have to say.

I listened to an interview on shortwave radio years back with a reporter from the BBC. He had spent 2 years in Northern China with Christian missionaries who were doing search and rescue for NK defectors.  China turned a blind eye for may years but for reasons not explained began rounding up defectors to send them back.  They said they were easy to find because they were all 8-10 inches shorter than the average Chinese adults.  They mentioned a 23 year old woman they found.  The first thing they did was feed her.  She asked what was on her plate, she had never seen or had beef.  At one time you had to be 5'9 to join the NK Army.  In the 90's they had to lower it to 5'7.  No one was growing to 5'9 anymore, they famine had been so bad for so long.   The BBC has been able to get footage of the mass graves that look like strip mines.

What is happening in north korea is so, so wrong, but I also think what the girl said about happiness is right -- the more well off a country, with more tiny choices that aren't as obvious as life and death for individuals to choose, the more we as a society find hard to find peace within ourselves.  Sometimes, hardships bring people together, and as a society without one hardship that brings us all together, with no hard choices except about a gazillion significant or insignificant we are not entirely sure paths and choices ahead of us, we falter, and that is not good.  Sometimes, money money money and more money and sometimes you forget who you are.  Other times, no money, in a world that needs it, without people by your side -- or money, but no people. Without hardships, sometimes you forget about the other people suffering out there.  That's why we have to all  acheive and live UP to our dreams -- so we can change ourselves and the world, and see the bigger picture, and find true happiness, for ourselves, and everyone around us -- whether that is becoming the next president, journying 360 around the world, raising a family in a small house in a small town, or whatever, anything. These videos are fantastic.  Thank you to Asian Boss, the interviewer and the defectors for providing insight into their lives in both North & South Korea.

It's really hard for the western society to understand that even in countries like North Korea, there are just normal people, thinking their minds, living their lives. It annoys me, when especially American documentaries portray NK as some kind of nuclear threat full of crazy mindless zombies, that just has to be neutralized. Propaganda works both ways, it seems.  There are only few very good documentary films, such as the one done by ARTE, but they are German or French. Also, there is an excellent Google Talk by Siegfried Hecker in English about their nuclear program here on YouTube ("What I Saw in North Korea and Why it Matters"), where you soon realize that NK relations are not just black and white, good and evil. There is a lot of stuff going on, and history has not been kind to the divided Korea. Especially what the Bush administration did with their "axis of evil" rubbish was unforgivable, and did not help the people there in any way.  It feels to me, North Korea is the scapegoat, and the US has no real interest in stabilizing the whole situation there. That does not mean, I want to excuse the horrible things the NK leadership does to its people, as an act of self-preservation, of course. But you have to know things like President Carter once had very good relations to the NK government, in order to understand how frustrating diplomatic relations have become.  The country and its culture and history is very interesting, yet sort of sad and frustrating, but lots of people don't really care or even know about it. I really really wish for more empathy there from the west, and that the country opens up soon and makes a reunion at least again a possibility.

This is harrowing, but oh so important to watch. I think that the western media should focus less on scaremongering the public around the ideas of North Korea's military goals. Instead we should be looking at the people of North Korea to see where common ground lies, and where the surrounding world can introduce the freedom-hungry youth to a better way of life.

+kippenoma They went the socialist root ( that is government ownership of the production and distribution of  goods and services ) eliminating classes and private property. The high ranking bureaucrats enjoyed the benefits of political inequality from their ends and kept it that way ( this is what hayek referred to as fascism).  Communism is as marx would put it the "Dictatorship of the proletariat", where the 'working class' rule, 'collective ownership triumph over private property and finally a 'utopia' where everyone can act hand in hand  "From each according to his ability, to each according to his need".  Sounds nice, fluffy and cuddly yet seldom those who advocate for such a framework will define the "abilities and needs" let alone address the elimination of competition and profit incentive (which necessitates innovation and protection for all parties in voluntary transactions), Hayek's knowledge problem ( i.e no matter how intelligent or abundant the bureaucrats are, it is IMPOSSIBLE for them to match the knowledge of millions who constantly engage in voluntary transactions within different fields of disciplines as formulated by the free market),  'collective ownership' and of course scarcity (as it will ALWAYS be both cheaper and more efficiently  represented by the price mechanism determined by supply and demand which immediately conveys information to both buyers and sellers aiding in prohibitive decision making and allocating scarce resources more efficiently .)   Self interested bureaucrats cannot match the consistency and accuracy in conveying information and has almost always lead to either artificial shortages or  surpluses. ( the imposition of price floors in agriculture 1932 in the great depression, aimed to restore 'parity' between the farmers implanted through supply regulation and buying the excess supply. And ofc the rate of poverty increased until WW2 and the proceeding economic boom.)   The important thing to understand here, is that individuals seek to satisfy their own separate interests AND THAT INCLUDES the bureaucrats. There are no angels, thus the best system is a system which promotes individual responsibility, economic and political freedoms.

Well, I know the cops do the same thing when witnessing something like a gruesome crime scene. I remember one cop telling me about this time that they went to the scene of a crash, and there was all kinds of bodies, some impaled and hanging in the air, some decapitated, some with their guts strewn about, and they just started cracking jokes so that they wouldn't have to deal with the horrible sights. It just helps them cope.
Koreans often smile and laugh when they are nervous or uncomfortable. It's a cultural thing.

It's hard to say how she feels, because her experiences growing up are so different from most others. In the book Escape from Camp 14 Shin, who escaped, said he came to feel ashamed because he did not love his mother or father growing up-- he saw them as competition for food or even as enemies. Shin grew up in a prison camp, so his experiences are probably even more extreme than the average person living in North Korea, but it still must have an impact on their ability to express emotions.

I noticed many stand up comedians lived through major trauma. Bullying and poverty seem amongst the most common.  The funniest people I know either got past messed up childhoods or are veterans. I think they develop their sense of humor to help themselves and their peers cope.

Yeah, I was a little off-put by the occasional giggle and chuckle. I'm sitting here like "why the hell is she laughing when she talks about her family getting possibly executed?".  I guess she's either desensitized a bit or hopefully just trying to humor the situation.
Interesting that more people saw this very same thing, It felt indeed like a mask that she wears.

When something happens around you constantly it stops being traumatizing and starts being normal. Like she said many North Koreans are happy, because as people we always hold onto what good we can find in life regardless of our situation. People in NK see executions and stuff like that daily and it's not stigmatized, so it just doesn't bother them.
Marnie I felt the same thing. for me it was a little disturbing since the thing they saw, they just smile it off but deep inside they know how scary it is

I remember hearing that after... I think it was WW1 (may have been WW2 though), the british soldiers recovered from the trauma of the war faster than most of the others because of their ability to make use of gallows humor. Laughing at horrendously traumatic stuff is most likely a coping mechanism.   I also have the "laughing at inappropriate things" issue though. I had a sociopath (Diagnosed officially) for a father and lived through a bunch of abusive crap as a kid (my older brother had it worse) but for some reason after that ended and even now I still find myself laughing at stuff I don't find funny. Like I'll feel sad about something and start laughing or whatever. It might just be a result of abuse, I'm not totally sure honestly.  I don't entirely remember but I have read about certain neurological conditions that can result in the wiring around things like... the more emotional parts of the brain essentially being messed up or mis-wired so to speak. I don't know if that's the reason why but regardless it's weird.  Regardless, I feel reminded of why I should be grateful my childhood was as good as it was. I used to think that having had such a close up look at evil was incredibly useful in knowing how people like my father behave, and I was definitely grateful for that. Now I just feel grateful that I was never in danger of starving to death, that I had luxuries that kids in some places would kill for (like air conditioning and 24 hour electricity). This video, weirdly enough, caused me to feel both horrified and tremendously grateful for the fact that my life is as good as it has been. I mean I already felt grateful for my life (been pretty damn great after I got away from my father) but I used to think I'd probably rather die than have to do everything all over a second or third time, but I think I just might rather live through it all 4 or 5 times than living through North Korea even once.  Just... I hope things improve for them sometime soon.

Yes- I had bodywork done on me relatively recently that was pretty "deep" - I was very sensitive/ticklish and couldn't help laughing but emotionally I was always sobbing on the inside and my physical therapy/body worker told me he'd learned once that the pathways in the brain with laughter or crying are very close/some of the same pathways- they're both emotionally relieving- and both can happen during either comedy or tragedy- sometimes pain is so much physically you'll just start laughing- anyone besides me experienced this? This is what I was feeling at the time. Some things were just so tight they couldn't relax and were very ticklish- other things were so tight they hurt like a B*?!~ to release and I laughed the same. Same thing can happen win emotional pain I think from time to time. It's lightweight hysteria.
It's cultural, I still do it even though I'm a Korean living in NZ because I picked it up from my parents.

You can see and hear her worry whenever she spoke about the unknown fate of her family.   None of her laughter sounded like she was laughing because she was happy about it or fond of the time. There's such a thing as laughing to reduce the impact of unpleasant things.  They are happy with each other. That they have family and that they still love, not happy that they were still starving. And, as they said--people were dying of starvation, and there wasn't enough food in North Korea. Staying meant likely death.  She still has some living family--she's been in contact with her sisters. Remember, they said that the killing of the whole family rather than just the escapee began with Kim Jong-un; they both left during the rule of Kim Jong-il.  As they pointed out, it was effectively capitalism under the veil of communism. They still had money, just a shitty small amount of it; if you're leaving, you can afford to blow everything you have left for a bribe, or you could sell all the possessions you can't carry with you.  As for the military--that's where paranoia comes into play. North Korea's a fascist police state where you can be reported on by anybody. There are rewards for turning in defectors, and for a member of the military to abandon post to run away would be a significantly worse crime than just any old civilian trying to escape. If they tried to escape themselves, another soldier there might shoot them. If they tried to talk about it first or convince others to escape with them, they might be snitched on (arguably worse than just getting killed running away). If they try to have mercy on someone escaping and not shoot, they could be reported on for sympathizing with traitors.  How North Koreans escape and the travesties they have to go through (which can last a while after escape--there are a few human trafficking groups that trick North Koreans into "escaping" with them)  has been pretty well documented--a few ex-North Koreans have even written books about it, like Park Yeon-mi. I believe there are a couple of other ways they've been known to escape besides the river, as well.

16:15 That development in human mentality is called "Maslow's hierarchy of needs". Every human being subconsciously desires to fulfill a certain need depending on their current situation.  Firstly, an individuals survival instincts; the natural drive to be alive (food, water, rest).  Once that's not an issue, other desires like security/safety. Next is a human's need of love and belonging. Thirdly, feeling of accomplishment and finally, self-actualization.
