Depends on how you define "significant". North Korean accent is a little bit different than your usual Seoul accent and they have different words for a lot of stuff, like Hangul (the Korean alphabet) is called "Chosongul" in North Korea, friend is "chingu" in South while it's tongmu in North. Also South Korea has borrowed a lot of English words, but North Korea has borrowed a number of Russian and Eastern European words. So there are a lot of differences when it comes to technology related words and even country names (like Poland in North is "Polsuka" and it's actually borrowed from Polish while it's just "Polandu" in South, obviously borrowed from English).   So North and South Korean are kind of like American and British English.
DarkbloomTV Or maybe Hindi and Urdu? Anyway, very cool thanks a lot.

the mechanism of korean (hangeul) is way different from that of alphabet.  To make a readable letter, it requires 1 consonant in front, 1 vowel following it and sometimes 1 another consonant following former 2.  so in this case, 'pol' alone formed a letter already and 's' can not form a letter since it is followed by another consonant. So they just add 'u' after 's' to make it sound as similar as the original pronunciation.

It has indeed. Since North Korea and South Korea separated, the north has hardly experienced any development. While the south was also allied with the United States, this influenced their vocabulary and brought a lot of english words/terminology into their language. North Korea however, still uses words and phrases that are straight out of the 1960's. The influence of english on the (south) korean language has proved to be a difficult adjustment for many north korean defectors that come to the south. What's more, the education/studies north koreans did in their own country are not seen as eligible in south korea, for example in the medicinal field. While South Korea is the world's 11th largest economy the north is decades behind. This also means that their medicinal and scientific research has very much fallen back. If a defector that was say a doctor/nurse in the north wishes to continue practicing medicine professionally in the south, they must redo all of their studies in order to update them to south korean standards... this includes learning all the new english terminology that is used in south korean medicine nowadays. Hope this answered your question... sorry it was so long haha

This is a third-hand anecdote, but when I was teaching in South Korea, one of my coworkers actually learned the language. He described himself as conversant, not fluent, but he understood South Koreans easily enough. However, he said that when he watched documentaries about North Korea, he was able to understand the grandparents but not the kids due to the language divergence. Take that as you will.

+Rosaraider Yes you're right. even some young north korean defectors that went to south korean and enrolled in south Korea's school have problems understanding koreans as their wordings, language has changed. South Korean can easily detect a North Korean based on their dialects too.
Oh, and actually Polsuka isn't correct pronunciation. The exact pronunciation is somewhat between 'polsoka' and 'polsuka'.

I grew up in South Korea roughly for the first half of my life. There had already been regional dialects across different parts of Korea before the split, and people could mostly understand each other despite differences in the intonation and usage of words (perhaps with an exception of the Jeju island dialect which is extraordinarily different from the rest of the dialects).    After the division of the country, both the North and the South declared Pyongyang and Seoul dialects as their own "standard" languages, respectively.  As others have noted, each has diverged somewhat with North Korean heavily influenced by Russian and Chinese and South Korean by American English.  However, I noticed  North Korea seemed to put emphasis on preserving their own culture and language more than the South (perhaps because of the Internet, South Korean changes more rapidly).    Note that the defectors in the above video have lived in South Korea for a long time and as far as I can tell their Korean is very close to the standard South Korean.  When I watch videos of people in North Korea, I can understand about 98% of it.  So I believe while there are differences in the languages, they are not that great.
Probably. My brother's ex-girlfriend was from South Korea, and from my understanding, Koreans from the south had a different dialect even before the split.
Also, South Koreans use a lot of English loanwords, which North Koreans don't.

A lot of people commenting on their little laughter throughout describing grave things, but they forget to consider 1) Different culturals in general will often have their own common mannerisms at certain times, so always keep that in mind when observing or listening to someone outside of your own culture, but 2) The fact that they lived through what they described and it was their norm for so long, has left  them not without care or seriousness, but somewhat desensitized. For anyone living a much more comfortable life than what they had described, of course you will react differently. Laughing is a common accompaniment of discomfort, internationally, often in attempts to keep composure. They are not careless or cold to the topic, just different reactions will be seen on the outside of those who actually went through it. If that made sense.  I am happy they were able to escape and share the truth with us, so as to raise awareness.

Thing is, you cannot just attack a sovereign nation. And if you somehow do anyway like the U.S. recently did with Iraq and Russia even more recently did with Ukraine you are not only setting another precedent for the disrespect of nations (although quite justified in that case) but you are also risking a lot of lives, depending on how advanced North Koreas nuclear program is. On the other side, North Korea could eventually extort resources from it's neighboring countries under thread of nuclear first strike.  Essentially I believe something has to be done, but that is easier said than put into reality.  I wonder what North Koreas plans are, if they get attacked by a national force. Do they believe they can withstand the assault? Do they believe they can coerce the assault to stop? Do they believe their own forces would defect when faced with foreign intervention? Do they believe personal assigned to nuclear missile would go through with the launch order? Aren't there high ranking officers who defected, who are in the know regarding those things?

The problem with North Korea is that should it ever collapse, there would be an enormous drain on all its neighbors - especially South Korea and China - due to the massive wealth gap. Therefore, South Korea remains vigilant but non-directly aggressive and China maintains the status quo as a collapse would harm them.   The North Korean regime is kept in power due to these external factors, but there will eventually be a breaking point. I can see them deploying nuclear weapons on their own people should they ever be in their death throws.

This is very informative on the individuals of North Korea. All too often do I hear people from the west calling for the eradication of North Korea and inadvertently lumping the country's citizens with Kim Jong Un's regime.

Ironically, I can't see top comments from Korean. Most of the top comments are from Non-Koreans. Are we being ignorant? Well... yeah I think so.  Millions of family have been separated due to 1950 Korean War. My grandad's brother is missing in North Korea. We have no idea whether he is alive or not. We just assume that he passed away because my grandfather is around 80. Every time when our family gather up for family holidays, my grandfather would start talking about how his brother was and what they did when they were young. But the sad thing is the story repeats. Do you guys know what I mean? He has no other memories to reminisce, because the time they spent together was not long enough to bring up new stories for annual holidays. I don't know exactly when they were separated, but it's been a long time since they last met.  It would be around 60 years I believe. I have no way to know how he exactly feels, but what I know is he occassionally gets depressed whenever we laugh around during the holidays. He goes into his room and looks out the windows

When he said we make up stereo types about North Korea...I actually drew a complete blank. I literally don't even know enough about NK to even have stereo types. I know they are people living in a part of Asia, I know there have been things going on in their country that have been terrible for them, but I don't know the details of what those things are. But honestly, as he says, I rarely ever see things about N.Korea (I don't really have TV at home, so most of what I know is what I find...like this and through self research), and in terms of studying countries, N.Korea isn't one I have gotten to yet. I've studied more about Japan and China so far, as far as history from that region of the world. So....I really can't even formulate stereo types about them, even if that sounds strange, because they are currently amorphous in my knowledge base. Might be time I take a break from Japan and Ireland, and go learn more about Korea in general.  I know these kinds of things have happened in lots of countries in the past, and still do happen even elsewhere, but it was hard thinking of the lives these people must have lived, and the kind of fear those still there must live with every day.  I know only a little of this first hand. When I was little, at times we could not afford electricity, and no heat during the winter (in a state where below 0 Fahrenheit is common), and our mom would go stretches with out eating so she could feed my sister and I what ever she could get. When I moved for college, couldn't find a job, and my money ran out, I spent almost a year knowing what it's like to be so hungry you stop feeling the signs of hunger, other then you are tired all of the time, and even moving becomes a tiring task, but you still do it. I started sleeping pretty much any time I didn't need to be some where for classes, because it conserved energy and I didn't get hungry until later in the day, and I would snitch food where I  could.  I don't even know anymore how I managed to get through classes most days now. But for the things I've been through, I know none of it was even a scratch compared to what people must be dealing with over there, and that my life has been many many times easier then theirs, even during my bleak times where at least I can still afford eggs and a bag of rice, even if that's what I end up eating for every mean for several months. A five pound bag of rice would be a blessing to families there, even more so then it was to me this last summer.

This is one of the bigger reasons why countries tend to stray away from getting involved as if NK gets to its breaking point and decides to drop a couple bombs, we could see this possible loss of 10s of millions of lives. We know north korea has a shortage of power, you can see on satellite imagery that it's practically a dark zone at night compared to south korea, china, and japan. I'm not really sure how much power they have exactly, but even countries with some exports and some semblance of a functional economy often struggle to keep a stable electrical grid. Kathmandu in Nepal is infamous for scheduled blackouts because they can't run the entire grid simultaneously. People in remote areas don't have power at all, they use car batteries and solar panels to charge phones and run a few basic items. In the great depression in the USA it wasn't that uncommon for electricians to re-connect people's electricity when it would get cut off, and even the people at the utility itself might be bribed into turning a blind eye to stuff like this. It's possible in some areas they've hacked the electrical grid and strung up lines to try and get electricity when it is disconnected, or have a similar solar panel battery system that maybe gives them power a few hours per day for a few small devices like a portable dvd player(which doesn't use much power). They might save up to buy alkaline batteries and play until the batteries run out and not play again until they can find more, which is common in many developing parts of the world.  These are just thoughts that popped into my head, there may be many explanations for the discrepancies.   I'm not sure what their incentives would be to lie, is north korea really a utopia and all the "refugees" are just south korean operatives trained to convey horror stories, because south korea and the usa are so jealous of north korea's success? Tons of watchdog organizations have reported on the horrors going on in north korea, i don't think it's unsubstantiated.

My friend's sister travels to North Korea once or twice a year to do relief work. They eat a lot of pine tree bark, which is boiled to make a paste or (less frequently) ground and mixed with flour or corn powder, sometimes baked into a sort of cake. They get tofu and corn meal or corn powder, and there are are other "wild foods" they resort to eating, such as grass, herbs, roots, and mushrooms, and sometimes rats or snakes. That said, things aren't quite as bad as they were in the 90s during the famine. The closer to Pyongyang you get, the better conditions are.

Good discussion going on here, but there is one thing: The idea of negative calorie foods is an old wive's tale.  Foods like cabbage are very low calorie, but your body only needs to burn 8% - 10% of those calories to digest them.  From what I've been able to find online, a cup of raw, shredded cabbage gives you around 15 calories after taking into account the digestive process.

Dallas You are absolutely right, 15 calories per cup is not enough to keep you healthy.  Also, even if you did eat enough to get enough calories (if you could eat that much) you still aren't getting enough nutrients.  So, while I agree with the sentiment that cabbage alone isn't enough to sustain people, it isn't technically negative calories.

It's a mistake to think that people are "happy" when their basic human needs aren't being unfulfilled/ignored, such as food. Generally, the more your income is, the happier you are, because it's easier to get your basic needs met. But beyond a point, additional income makes you less happy because it consumes more of your time and energy and isolates you from the community. Overall, people are happiest in countries where basic human needs are treated with respect and dignity by the law.

Beartoe Con Carne Capitalism:  1. Destroys the environment. It must expand into as many avenues of production as possible as the forces of social reaction (eg conservatism, populism, etc) will allow. The wanton destruction of the environment as we see and experience everyday is proof of this.  2. Exploits workers. Mainstream bourgeois economists cannot explain the failure of Keynesian economics in the stagflation of the 70's as well as recently in 2008 monetarist policies and neoliberalism. They blame external forces interfering with their theory like immigration or outlier agents in the market. However, it is because they have abandoned the labour theory of value (LTV), ie that the source of all exchange-value is socially necessary, homogeneous labour.  The LTV explains an inconvenient truth for economists: that exchange in capitalism is zero-sum. That in turn has the consequence that, in order for companies to turn a profit â€” to even stay afloat! â€” they must exploit workers; in order words, they must take from the worker, who is alienated from their labour inputs by wages, surplus value.  3. Amplifies and sustains racism, sexism, transphobia, homophobia, etc. So long as the workers as distracted by identity politics, they will at best see class as yet another part of identity and nothing more, and perhaps even call for class collaboration like fasces. So long as there is division within the working class, consumption and selling one's labour for less will be widespread. Competition relies on worker disunity.  Capitalism does not create these problems. However, so long as it is allowed to fester, solidarity for the vast majority of people on earth will be impossible. And if the left fails, capitalism will turn to fascism to foster worker division directly.  4. Creates artificial scarcity. We produce at least 1.5 times the food all humans need to eat but this is wasted by corporations because it is profitable. Empty houses in the US outnumber homeless people 6:1.  5. Creates planned obsolescence. iPhones and Samsung mobiles go out of date in a flash because it is more profitable to design newer, subtly different models.  6. Diminishes the middle class. The state apparatus taxes the middle class heavily to subsidise companies through government policies like welfare, forcing the great mass of them eventually either into the proletariat and the remaining few into the capitalist class, or turning them into a body for far right militancy.  7. Spreads war and imperialism. Capitalism is forced to look abroad to a. drive competition and force workers to sell labour for less in the name of "the war effort" and nationalism; b. accumulate capital and expand its industry; and c. create demand for weapon and ammunition manufacture and the military.  8. Alienates us from society and our work. This is a complex topic, but we see that capitalism alienates us by estranging us from our products by wages, making work feel drudgerous by limiting organic labour in favour of wage labour, by turning education away from fulfillment and into repetition and regurgitation, by dehumanising us as in turning us from fellow human to cogwheel in the machine, and so on.  9. Creates inevitable economic crises. Marx concludes in his crisis theory, from the LTV and the work of classical economists, that boom and bust cycles cannot be escaped. Bankers fall; companies fall; the bulk of society is chained down and breaks down with the market economy of exchange-value and its abstractions and internal contradictions. You cannot reform this away.  In addition it creates super-bacteria due to over-prescription of antibiotics, prevents a collective move towards veganism, and a whole deluge of other problems.  So how do we change this? The problems are too severe. Continual reform with no end in sight is but a bandaid to what is clearly a massive slice to the jugular. We cannot look to the state. We know through the extensive work of countless historians and political scientists that there is real class struggle everywhere since time immemorial, or in Marxist terms, the lens of historical materialism has been and continues to be affirmed. To take reform (or "infiltration") of the state apparatus which serves the bourgeois as primary is not only futile, it is also a betrayal of the interests of the working class. We must look outside of the state and within capitalism for answers.  Where do the multiple "evils" of capitalism stem from? They result from the various internal contradictions of capital, which all come from the conditions necessary for society to be capitalistic: a. exchange in the market; b. the commodification of labour, sold for a wage by the proletariat; and c. the ownership of private property by the bourgeoisie. The relations of production are the basis of the class divide; in this way, class is defined concretely.  The solution, then, is to negate all three of these. If not a market, then what? An intimate network of central pools of resources. If not relations of production, then what? Classless societies. If not private property, then what? The bifurcation of private property into either public or personal property.  Historically, shifts and changes in the structure of society have been accompanied by developments in the technological forces of production. The bourgeois-democratic revolutions throughout Europe in which the state became increasingly dominated by the then-mercantile now-bourgeois class could only have been possible with the advent of the Industrial Revolution. So we must not tire.  Quantitative change inevitably leads to some foreign interruption or natural qualitative change. We must either head towards revolution or collective ruin.

nubemuffin I find it very funny that you say, very correctly, that China is (and arguably has been since the era of Mao) state capitalist. And then you say that communist countries are poor; except there have been no communist countries except the self-proclaimed ones. If you put in the same level of analysis in these allegedly "communist" countries as you did in China, you would find that they are nothing more than simply less liberal forms of capitalism.

Communisation China was very much communist during the great leap forward. Land was nationalized, private enterprise was forbidden, and people were sent to work on communal farms. It was textbook Marxism, and if failed as it always has and always will.   Also, you rambled quite a bit and I don't have the time to cover all of your topics.  However, the idea that a market is a zero sum game is a really simplistic and archaic view of markets. Production is determined by the input factors that go into producing it. These factors can be accumulated and improved upon making production more efficient and therefore requiring less resources to produce the same amount. For example, there are far less resources needed to produce a computer capable of calculating simple math (a calculator) today than was needed 50 years ago.  It's undeniable that our productive capacities have increased over time. We are capable today of producing more than we ever have. In economics, this is called real GDP. This increase in real GDP completely disproves your zero sum theory. Those new products have to go to someone which means that the market can't be zero sum since new products are being added to it.  You may wrongly conclude that this increase in real production is just a result of the exploitation of the environment. However, the invisible hand does an amazing job of fixing exploitation problems. When a resource becomes more scared (due to the overuse of it in the market), the supply of that resource shifts left and the market clears at a higher price. This higher price will result in a lower amount being demanded and consumers will switch to other more available and cheaper alternatives. In the past, many simple minded folks concluded that the world consumption would exceed production capacity by now. They assumed we would use up all of our resources and starve. However, it's clear to everyone that they were wrong.  One other thing I'd like to touch on: The idea that capitalism harms minority populations.  You'll find that if you really examine the situation, capitalism can only help minority populations. In state controlled markets, the goods a person has available to consume is determined entirely by the government. Governments will be controlled by the majority populations. It's very easy (and often happens) for the government to use a minority population as a scapegoat or treat them as some sort of "other" and deprive them of the necessary goods required for survival.  Capitalism on the other hand, results in an entirely different situation prevailing. In capitalism, people only care about profit. This gives minority populations opportunity to compete and make a living by selling their products at cheaper prices (if there is some discrimination present in the market and there goods come at a discount), allowing them to make a living. The market doesn't care a pair of shoes were put together by a black, white, asian, green, or purple person. It's impersonal.

UnderGat45 Let me be clear: I argue for and defend neither UBI nor the USSR. The flimsy human nature "argument" has been trotted out since time immemorial (or, at least, whenever the status quo feels the need to assert itself and the validity of its oppression). Therefore, I will give you my standard response.  'The social form of people's regular activities under capitalism is a response to a certain material and historical situation. The material and historical conditions explain the origin of the capitalist form, but do not explain why this form continues after the initial situation disappears. A concept of "cultural lag" is not an explanation of the continuity of a social form after the disappearance of the initial conditions to which it responded. This concept is merely a name for the continuity of the social form. When the concept of "cultural lag" parades as a name for a "social force" which determines human activity, it is an obfuscation which presents the outcome of people's activities as an external force beyond their control. This is not only true of a concept like "cultural lag." Many of the terms used by Marx to describe people's activities have been raised to the status of external and even "natural" forces which determine people's activity; thus concepts like "class struggle," "production relations" and particularly "The Dialectic," play the same role in the theories of some "Marxists" that "Original Sin," "Fate" and "The Hand of Destiny" played in the theories of medieval mystifiers.  'In the performance of their daily activities, the members of capitalist society simultaneously carry out two processes: they reproduce the form of their activities, and they eliminate the material conditions to which this form of activity initially responded. But they do not know they carry out these processes; their own activities are not transparent to them. They are under the illusion that their activities are responses to natural conditions beyond their control and do not see that they are themselves authors of those conditions. The task of capitalist ideology is to maintain the veil which keeps people from seeing that their own activities reproduce the form of their daily life; the task of critical theory is to unveil the activities of daily life, to render them transparent, to make the reproduction of the social form of capitalist activity visible within people's daily activities.  'Under capitalism, daily life consists of related activities which reproduce and expand the capitalist form of social activity. The sale of labor-time for a price (a wage), the embodiment of labortime in commodities (saleable goods, both tangible and intangible), the consumption of tangible and intangible commodities (such as consumer goods and spectacles)-these activities which characterize daily life under capitalism are not manifestations of "human nature," nor are they imposed on men by forces beyond their control.  'If it is held that man is "by nature" an uninventive tribesman and an inventive businessman, a submissive slave and a proud craftsman an independent hunter and a dependent wage-worker, then either man's "nature" is an empty concept, or man's "nature'' depends on material and historical conditions, and is in fact a response to those conditions.'  â€” Fredy Perlman, The Reproduction of Everyday Life

While they are extremely picky about who can enter the country, from my point of view it is not the same as being completely closed off.   There was a Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in North Korea; I can recommend checking it out to get more context from a somewhat reliable source of information. There also exist various organizations trying to improve the famine situation a bit through various means, but admittedly the effectiveness of such efforts might not be very good at the moment. In my opinion, change of policy might be one of the best ways to induce North Korea to open up more, but the international community should also be careful not to cause a war that nobody benefits from. I believe UN for instance has tried to push things towards that direction, but it doesn't seem to be one of their top priorities due to the high difficulty.  I tried to make the point that there are many people in somewhat similar situations regarding their options, but who are much more within our reach to help. As an individual, if it is not be possible to help everybody, don't you think that we should focus on making our efforts go as far as possible? Organizations like GiveWell have made lots of excellent research towards that direction; http://effective-altruism.com/ is another place where one could get good ideas regarding that.  Lastly, I'm not trying to say that we should neglect the North Korean situation by any means. If you feel like doing something for them, trying to contact people who have worked from that angle before might yield some better insight on the issue. It is also worth noting that interesting videos like these go a long way towards increasing awareness. Either way, I hope to see the world of tomorrow as a better place for everyone. Good luck.

Apart from the whole "They've got a nuke" and "But Russia and China are their allies"-stuff, there is a diplomatic reason. If we would attack a country based on the way we believe they are mistreating their own population, we're setting a standard for global war. Because we may feel that their way is incorrect, the might feel our way is incorrect. Your premise leans heavily on the subject of objective morality, while morality is a strictly subjective concept. On top of that, look at the many countries that have similar systems. China might not be half as bad as North Korea, but there are a lot of similar systems in place there. What of Saudi Arabia, where the islamic police stopped rescue workers from entering a burning school to save 15 girls that were still inside, just because the girls in question were not properly dressed (which is to say they weren't wearing headscarves and abayas). Would such policies warrant attacking a country? If we were to accept the invasion of North Korea based on the way they treat their own people, then we are opening up the doors for total war.

Neither Russia nor China want North Korea's regime to collapse, they'd see that as a greater threat to them than the current regime, because it would mean a UN/US western friendly government would likely replace it.   The UN can't interfere, because they have to consider how the two local superpowers would perceive it.   South Korea can't act because, while they have arguably more advanced weaponry and more money/supplies, North Korea has Nuclear weapons. Also, there's probably not much the US or UN could do to justify helping, if South Korea was the one to start a conflict. Not to mention, while its equipment is outdated and they could barely feed it, North Korea still has a large army.   Long story short, the only quick way for things to happen is if an uprising succeeded within North Korea itself and they then asked the UN and/or South Korea for help. It would be hard for Russia/China to stop them, at that point. Even still, it would take billions of Dollars from the South Korean and international community to stabilize them. It's not as simple as just rewriting the map and calling the peninsula "Korea" again.

OP's arguments are formed from idealism and ignore the complicated intricacies of geopolitics. I used to think the exact same thing before I actually learned how the world works: "if America really cared about freedom they would invade North Korea, not Iraq!".  But here's why this opinion is incompatible with reality: first of all, a war isn't fought by the dictator, but by the people. You're literally saying "let's kill North Koreans to save them!". Kim will throw human shields towards the rockets until there's not one single North Korean left to use as cannon fodder. Second of all, North Korea has nukes. More primitive ones, but nukes nonetheless, capable of destroying nearby cities like Seoul or Tokyo. Imagine that. Imagine a nuke exploding over a 10-15 mil population metropolis. Third of all, you have China which guarantees North Korea's independence. The Kim dynasty needs a strong friend and China needs a buffer between itself and South Korea. This alliance is based on mutual need rather than ideology. So going to war with North Korea would also mean effectively making China your enemy.

leastcommondinominat It's not greed.  It's built into the so-called "free market".  If one person cheats or does something exploitative, it puts them at an advantage which effectively puts others who don't join out of business and therefore their livelihood.  This causes an evergrowing chain reaction on multiple fronts which inevitably leads to an inevitable end, with growing mass inequality.  That's of course bring relevance to where you'd predominantly be getting this idea from, ironically, from the stratifying and "individualistic" culture that's born out of this.  In other cases, it's always been things which were structurally incentivized.  The problem with human nature is that its reactionary, so when scarcity and inequality are an issue, it's always going to lead to conflict.  The only way for this to not be an issue isn't in particular any kind of arrangement of government, but rather, the building of an economy that's based around post-scarcity.  With the technology we have today, and no, not just in some Utopian fantasy, it's possible today to accomplish this if enough people actually came to this understanding who are in charge of serious production.  We have more than enough resources for this to be a reality - certainly to meet basic/base-level human needs.  I find it funny when people think they've actually been met in the current system we live in, just because most of the population have a roof over their head.  The biggest problem with Communism was that it wasn't technically accountable and it was still a money-based economy (as all economies in the world today) rather than a resource-based one.  Money is the thing, in the value it's assigned relative to resources (and therefore influence and power), which differentiates people by status and inevitably leads to clashing converging interests.  It's impossible to account for in the way you suggested simply because of the inevitable runaway effect that this eventually has.  I wouldn't really place the root of this at human nature.

***** Marx would have been right to consider it impossible at the time.  There also wouldn't be a need or a place to even have a ruling class in a Resource Based Economy.  There's a lot to read up on and look into before making the assertion you just have.

***** I agree with all of that and never implied the contrary.  The myth today is that what Capitalism allows or can continue to otherwise do is empower the common man.  What I would disagree with is the clear conflation, even if not explicitly made, between GDP and standard of living.  GDP it grows, it CERTAINLY does that, but past a certain point the charts of standard of living and GDP are essentially inversely related.  As one of the reasons I imagine you therefore mentioned, it's all a mix and a very necessary one.  In terms of it being the strongest system to date, my point was this: that it was*.  There isn't physically existing a better one but it's certainly no longer workable in any balance or mixture and there are ideas to better take its place.  My reference point for any of this isn't actually something like Marxism, something that was was conceived over a century ago.  The current aggregate of the best information we have comes in the form of The Zeitgeist Movement and other things which center around the idea of a Resource Based Economy.

***** Well, this is an insanely long conversation, not exactly one for YouTube comments, but one thing I would reinforce though is, again, our current system no longer is in any way in favor of the common man. No.  Inequality has widened because globalization and technological change have made most people less competitive, while making the best educated more competitive. What people used to do can now be done more cheaply by lower-paid workers abroad or by computer-driven machines. Now take into account intellectual property rights being extended and enlarged creating windfalls for pharmaceutical  companies which in turn caused prices to skyrocket in comparison to other advanced nations, antitrust laws having been relaxed for corporations with significant market power, such as big food companies, cable companies facing little or no broadband competition, big airlines and the largest Wall Street banks, again causing Americans to pay more for these services than any other advanced nation, bankruptcy laws being extended for large corporations but not homeowners, and many more. None of these are fixed by socialism, they are in fact the cause of socialist dipping in our current system. These are all laws and policies passed in an attempt to enforce democratic centralism, which is a socialist political tenet of Marxism. Justin Flynn That's a very unsophisticated conception of freedom. By that standard, you're better off living by yourself in a hut in the woods and hunting to live. But since we are a social species and that social species always form hierarchies (even penguins!), the challenge is to end up with the least oppressive hierarchy possible and we have been inching closer and closer to that through centuries of fights for greater enfranchisement and more rights in a number of countries. A few things have gone backwards but by and large, the modern democratic state with universal suffrage, guaranteed rights, freedom of the press and freedom of association (syndicalism) largely safeguards individual freedoms from both tyranny and mob justice.  Let's play a simple thought experiment: tomorrow you wake up and there is no State left. No police, no army, no taxes, no welfare, no enforceable regulations or laws. Well me and a dozen of my buddies are going to pool our ressources together to acquire military grade heavy weaponry just as hundreds of armed groups are going to start forming out there. And we are going to come to your house, farm or whatever and give you a choice between buying our protection for half of what you manage to make each week or we pillage through everything you've got now. Congratulations, you now live under a feodal system. How did you enjoy those 2 seconds of freedom? The modern democratic State has created the conditions for the freest societies in the history of civilisation. There is still a lot to criticise but yeah...

SUM1 You seem to not be very informed as to what is occurring with ISIS right now. Or what happened with Hitler's regime prior to the rest of the world stepping in. Mishro22 Think about what you're saying. What "establishment"? Where are these people coming from that make up the establishment? They inevitably have to come from or at least be supported by the people they're ruling over, as if they weren't they couldn't exist. "Kim Jong Un and his establishment" are inevitably members of the North Korean population, and therefore couldn't "wipe out" themselves unless a larger faction of the population was opposed to them. Point is, there is no such thing as a "dictator", it is impossible for a state to exist without the support of its people or a foreign power.  Yes, in this respect, it is well known that most Germans under Nazi Germany supported the NSDAP and they are what led to its rise (due to a combination of huge economic crises and a humiliation after the defeat of WWI), and there are clearly enough active members of the Sunni ISIS force to hold territory and population for many years, meaning they do not go unsupported. They are the Sunni faction which opposes US domination and Assad domination. The Islamist "rebels" oppose Assad domination but ally with US aid and armed forces. The Kurds are the ethnic Western Iranian component who are also Sunni but are fighting for their ethnic rights, and the Assad family are a Shia power from the Western Shia Alawite Latakia region. They only held power for so long because they did it under the banner of Ba'athism and Arab nationalism, at a time when Ba'athist governments were more widespread and could support each other.  I think you'll find I am very informed about the origins of the Syrian war.

SUM1 The "establishment" I am referring to are the plethora of military and governmental support he has surrounded himself with that all benefit directly from his tyranny. You are correct, overall his nation requires the survival of the lowest tier to some extent, but that doesn't stop a sociopath from going crazy. If his low tier attempted a revolt, he would wipe them without a second thought. His grip is secured much more deeply than that of ISIS or Hitler because it has been burying its claws into the country for so many more years than the aforementioned. You could make the argument that Kim Jong Un is significantly more powerful than Hitler ever came close to, and much more than ISIS will ever be. He hasn't created global scale terror like the other two, but his regional grip and control is beyond description.

Mishro22 Again, what "grip" are you talking about? He didn't decide to be the next head of state of the DPRK nor could he control the millions of people needed nationwide to facilitate him being in his position. That would make no sense. So again, think about what you're saying. It must necessarily be that most people are supporting him and therefore keeping him in his position, worshipping him as a direct bloodline from Kim Il-sung, importantly the founder of the first independent Korea (in the north) after decades of Japanese rule. The Korean peninsula has a history of kingdoms and dynasties. It is a single dominant Korean ethnicity territory. North Korea is no different in that respect from those kingdoms. The main thing makes this different is that there was no head of state for 35 years under Japanese rule, and the Kim family bloodline happens to descend from the guerrilla leader who found his way into the first position of head of state in the north by way of Stalin and the Soviet Union.  So you could say in one respect that people do steadfastly support him and his words and actions as this figurehead and that gives him a so-called "grip", but you can't say that he is the one with the "grip" in reality, as that wouldn't be further from the truth. It's the larger part of the North Korean people who prop him up.

Much information about North Korea is filtered through South Korea, but the longstanding conflict between the two countries distorts the information that is received. Hi Jack its not just a cultural thing this is normal for us humans to laugh when things are tragic and terrible  it helps you to keep  going  on. the guy nor that lady could have kept telling their stories had they broken down into tears

my country has been war since I was 5 years until I was 9 (we moved) and all bombs bombed near us after that  the adults all laughed about it and joked for us to calm down  and now i think about it thanks to that i indured well with out laughing i  think i would had break down
her skin has been toughened by harsh realities, you cant compare her emotional reactions to the average joe

I'd guess it's more related to the living situation in North Korea, rather than a coping mechanism or a "what else can you do?" When you grow up watching everyone around you die, you just accept that it's going to happen to everyone. If death is so common, you look at everyone around you and think "it's as good as if they're already dead." So you deal with the grief possibly long before that person actually dies, and with time you get past it. She's probably been over the deaths of her family members for almost her entire life.

Asian culture is like that. No matter what you go through you keep a smile on your face and keep on going.

It's not exactly a secret you know. There are plenty of "brokers" who get paid to smuggle people out of North Korea, or smuggle Chinese goods into North Korea. The North Korean government is already aware of this, but it's difficult to stop every soldier from taking bribes. For North Korean soldiers, bribery is actually a way to make a living because military service is compulsory in North Korea and lasts for ten years. You can imagine that the government doesn't pay shit for their service, so soldiers rely on bribery to feed their families back home.
